  • django.db.models.sql.query
  • View page source

django.db.models.sql.queryÔÉÅ

Create SQL statements for QuerySets.

The code in here encapsulates all of the SQL construction so that QuerySets themselves do not have to (and could be backed by things other than SQL databases). The abstraction barrier only works one way: this module has to know all about the internals of models in order to get the information it needs.

ClassesÔÉÅ

RawQuery

A single raw SQL query.

Query

A single SQL query.

combine(rhs, connector)[source]ÔÉÅ

Merge the ‚Äòrhs‚Äô query into the current one (with any ‚Äòrhs‚Äô effects being applied after (that is, ‚Äúto the right of‚Äù) anything in the current query. ‚Äòrhs‚Äô is not modified during a call to this function.

The ‚Äòconnector‚Äô parameter describes how to connect filters from the ‚Äòrhs‚Äô query.

get_select_mask()[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert the self.deferred_loading data structure to an alternate data structure, describing the field that will be loaded. This is used to compute the columns to select from the database and also by the QuerySet class to work out which fields are being initialized on each model. Models that have all their fields included aren‚Äôt mentioned in the result, only those that have field restrictions in place.

table_alias(table_name, create=False, filtered_relation=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return a table alias for the given table_name and whether this is a new alias or not.

If ‚Äòcreate‚Äô is true, a new alias is always created. Otherwise, the most recently created alias for the table (if one exists) is reused.

ref_alias(alias)[source]ÔÉÅ

Increases the reference count for this alias.

unref_alias(alias, amount=1)[source]ÔÉÅ

Decreases the reference count for this alias.

promote_joins(aliases)[source]ÔÉÅ

Promote recursively the join type of given aliases and its children to an outer join. If ‚Äòunconditional‚Äô is False, only promote the join if it is nullable or the parent join is an outer join.

The children promotion is done to avoid join chains that contain a LOUTER b INNER c. So, if we have currently a INNER b INNER c and a->b is promoted, then we must also promote b->c automatically, or otherwise the promotion of a->b doesn‚Äôt actually change anything in the query results.

demote_joins(aliases)[source]ÔÉÅ

Change join type from LOUTER to INNER for all joins in aliases.

Similarly to promote_joins(), this method must ensure no join chains containing first an outer, then an inner join are generated. If we are demoting b->c join in chain a LOUTER b LOUTER c then we must demote a->b automatically, or otherwise the demotion of b->c doesn‚Äôt actually change anything in the query results. .

reset_refcounts(to_counts)[source]ÔÉÅ

Reset reference counts for aliases so that they match the value passed in to_counts.

change_aliases(change_map)[source]ÔÉÅ

Change the aliases in change_map (which maps old-alias -> new-alias), relabelling any references to them in select columns and the where clause.

bump_prefix(other_query, exclude=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Change the alias prefix to the next letter in the alphabet in a way that the other query‚Äôs aliases and this query‚Äôs aliases will not conflict. Even tables that previously had no alias will get an alias after this call. To prevent changing aliases use the exclude parameter.

get_initial_alias()[source]ÔÉÅ

Return the first alias for this query, after increasing its reference count.

count_active_tables()[source]ÔÉÅ

Return the number of tables in this query with a non-zero reference count. After execution, the reference counts are zeroed, so tables added in compiler will not be seen by this method.

join(join, reuse=None, reuse_with_filtered_relation=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return an alias for the ‚Äòjoin‚Äô, either reusing an existing alias for that join or creating a new one. ‚Äòjoin‚Äô is either a base_table_class or join_class.

The ‚Äòreuse‚Äô parameter can be either None which means all joins are reusable, or it can be a set containing the aliases that can be reused.

The ‚Äòreuse_with_filtered_relation‚Äô parameter is used when computing FilteredRelation instances.

A join is always created as LOUTER if the lhs alias is LOUTER to make sure chains like t1 LOUTER t2 INNER t3 aren‚Äôt generated. All new joins are created as LOUTER if the join is nullable.

join_parent_model(opts, model, alias, seen)[source]ÔÉÅ

Make sure the given ‚Äòmodel‚Äô is joined in the query. If ‚Äòmodel‚Äô isn‚Äôt a parent of ‚Äòopts‚Äô or if it is None this method is a no-op.

The ‚Äòalias‚Äô is the root alias for starting the join, ‚Äòseen‚Äô is a dict of model -> alias of existing joins. It must also contain a mapping of None -> some alias. This will be returned in the no-op case.

Add a single annotation expression to the Query.

resolve_expression(query, *args, **kwargs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) ‚Äì the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) ‚Äì boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) ‚Äì a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) ‚Äì a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) ‚Äì whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

get_external_cols()[source]ÔÉÅ
get_group_by_cols(wrapper=None)[source]ÔÉÅ
as_sql(compiler, connection)[source]ÔÉÅ

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‚Äòas_‚Äô + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) ‚Äì the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) ‚Äì the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

resolve_lookup_value(value, can_reuse, allow_joins, summarize=False)[source]ÔÉÅ
solve_lookup_type(lookup, summarize=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Solve the lookup type from the lookup (e.g.: ‚Äòfoobar__id__icontains‚Äô).

check_query_object_type(value, opts, field)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check whether the object passed while querying is of the correct type. If not, raise a ValueError specifying the wrong object.

check_related_objects(field, value, opts)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check the type of object passed to query relations.

check_filterable(expression)[source]ÔÉÅ

Raise an error if expression cannot be used in a WHERE clause.

build_lookup(lookups, lhs, rhs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Try to extract transforms and lookup from given lhs.

The lhs value is something that works like SQLExpression. The rhs value is what the lookup is going to compare against. The lookups is a list of names to extract using get_lookup() and get_transform().

try_transform(lhs, name)[source]ÔÉÅ

Helper method for build_lookup(). Try to fetch and initialize a transform for name parameter from lhs.

build_filter(filter_expr, branch_negated=False, current_negated=False, can_reuse=None, allow_joins=True, split_subq=True, reuse_with_filtered_relation=False, check_filterable=True, summarize=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Build a WhereNode for a single filter clause but don‚Äôt add it to this Query. Query.add_q() will then add this filter to the where Node.

The ‚Äòbranch_negated‚Äô tells us if the current branch contains any negations. This will be used to determine if subqueries are needed.

The ‚Äòcurrent_negated‚Äô is used to determine if the current filter is negated or not and this will be used to determine if IS NULL filtering is needed.

The difference between current_negated and branch_negated is that branch_negated is set on first negation, but current_negated is flipped for each negation.

Note that add_filter will not do any negating itself, that is done upper in the code by add_q().

The ‚Äòcan_reuse‚Äô is a set of reusable joins for multijoins.

If ‚Äòreuse_with_filtered_relation‚Äô is True, then only joins in can_reuse will be reused.

The method will create a filter clause that can be added to the current query. However, if the filter isn‚Äôt added to the query then the caller is responsible for unreffing the joins used.

add_filter(filter_lhs, filter_rhs)[source]ÔÉÅ
add_q(q_object)[source]ÔÉÅ

A preprocessor for the internal _add_q(). Responsible for doing final join promotion.

build_where(filter_expr)[source]ÔÉÅ
clear_where()[source]ÔÉÅ
build_filtered_relation_q(q_object, reuse, branch_negated=False, current_negated=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add a FilteredRelation object to the current filter.

add_filtered_relation(filtered_relation, alias)[source]ÔÉÅ
names_to_path(names, opts, allow_many=True, fail_on_missing=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Walk the list of names and turns them into PathInfo tuples. A single name in ‚Äònames‚Äô can generate multiple PathInfos (m2m, for example).

‚Äònames‚Äô is the path of names to travel, ‚Äòopts‚Äô is the model Options we start the name resolving from, ‚Äòallow_many‚Äô is as for setup_joins(). If fail_on_missing is set to True, then a name that can‚Äôt be resolved will generate a FieldError.

Return a list of PathInfo tuples. In addition return the final field (the last used join field) and target (which is a field guaranteed to contain the same value as the final field). Finally, return those names that weren‚Äôt found (which are likely transforms and the final lookup).

setup_joins(names, opts, alias, can_reuse=None, allow_many=True, reuse_with_filtered_relation=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Compute the necessary table joins for the passage through the fields given in ‚Äònames‚Äô. ‚Äòopts‚Äô is the Options class for the current model (which gives the table we are starting from), ‚Äòalias‚Äô is the alias for the table to start the joining from.

The ‚Äòcan_reuse‚Äô defines the reverse foreign key joins we can reuse. It can be None in which case all joins are reusable or a set of aliases that can be reused. Note that non-reverse foreign keys are always reusable when using setup_joins().

The ‚Äòreuse_with_filtered_relation‚Äô can be used to force ‚Äòcan_reuse‚Äô parameter and force the relation on the given connections.

If ‚Äòallow_many‚Äô is False, then any reverse foreign key seen will generate a MultiJoin exception.

Return the final field involved in the joins, the target field (used for any ‚Äòwhere‚Äô constraint), the final ‚Äòopts‚Äô value, the joins, the field path traveled to generate the joins, and a transform function that takes a field and alias and is equivalent to field.get_col(alias) in the simple case but wraps field transforms if they were included in names.

The target field is the field containing the concrete value. Final field can be something different, for example foreign key pointing to that value. Final field is needed for example in some value conversions (convert ‚Äòobj‚Äô in fk__id=obj to pk val using the foreign key field for example).

trim_joins(targets, joins, path)[source]ÔÉÅ

The ‚Äòtarget‚Äô parameter is the final field being joined to, ‚Äòjoins‚Äô is the full list of join aliases. The ‚Äòpath‚Äô contain the PathInfos used to create the joins.

Return the final target field and table alias and the new active joins.

Always trim any direct join if the target column is already in the previous table. Can‚Äôt trim reverse joins as it‚Äôs unknown if there‚Äôs anything on the other side of the join.

resolve_ref(name, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False)[source]ÔÉÅ
split_exclude(filter_expr, can_reuse, names_with_path)[source]ÔÉÅ

When doing an exclude against any kind of N-to-many relation, we need to use a subquery. This method constructs the nested query, given the original exclude filter (filter_expr) and the portion up to the first N-to-many relation field.

For example, if the origin filter is ~Q(child__name=‚Äôfoo‚Äô), filter_expr is (‚Äòchild__name‚Äô, ‚Äòfoo‚Äô) and can_reuse is a set of joins usable for filters in the original query.

We will turn this into equivalent of:
WHERE NOT EXISTS(

SELECT 1 FROM child WHERE name = ‚Äòfoo‚Äô AND child.parent_id = parent.id LIMIT 1

)

set_empty()[source]ÔÉÅ
is_empty()[source]ÔÉÅ
set_limits(low=None, high=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Adjust the limits on the rows retrieved. Use low/high to set these, as it makes it more Pythonic to read and write. When the SQL query is created, convert them to the appropriate offset and limit values.

Apply any limits passed in here to the existing constraints. Add low to the current low value and clamp both to any existing high value.

clear_limits()[source]ÔÉÅ

Clear any existing limits.

can_filter()[source]ÔÉÅ

Return True if adding filters to this instance is still possible.

Typically, this means no limits or offsets have been put on the results.

Remove all fields from SELECT clause.

clear_select_fields()[source]ÔÉÅ

Clear the list of fields to select (but not extra_select columns). Some queryset types completely replace any existing list of select columns.

add_select_col(col, name)[source]ÔÉÅ
set_select(cols)[source]ÔÉÅ
add_distinct_fields(*field_names)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add and resolve the given fields to the query‚Äôs ‚Äúdistinct on‚Äù clause.

add_fields(field_names, allow_m2m=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add the given (model) fields to the select set. Add the field names in the order specified.

add_ordering(*ordering)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add items from the ‚Äòordering‚Äô sequence to the query‚Äôs ‚Äúorder by‚Äù clause. These items are either field names (not column names) ‚Äì possibly with a direction prefix (‚Äò-‚Äô or ‚Äò?‚Äô) ‚Äì or OrderBy expressions.

If ‚Äòordering‚Äô is empty, clear all ordering from the query.

clear_ordering(force=False, clear_default=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Remove any ordering settings if the current query allows it without side effects, set ‚Äòforce‚Äô to True to clear the ordering regardless. If ‚Äòclear_default‚Äô is True, there will be no ordering in the resulting query (not even the model‚Äôs default).

set_group_by(allow_aliases=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Expand the GROUP BY clause required by the query.

This will usually be the set of all non-aggregate fields in the return data. If the database backend supports grouping by the primary key, and the query would be equivalent, the optimization will be made automatically.

add_select_related(fields)[source]ÔÉÅ

Set up the select_related data structure so that we only select certain related models (as opposed to all models, when self.select_related=True).

add_extra(select, select_params, where, params, tables, order_by)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add data to the various extra_* attributes for user-created additions to the query.

clear_deferred_loading()[source]ÔÉÅ

Remove any fields from the deferred loading set.

add_deferred_loading(field_names)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add the given list of model field names to the set of fields to exclude from loading from the database when automatic column selection is done. Add the new field names to any existing field names that are deferred (or removed from any existing field names that are marked as the only ones for immediate loading).

add_immediate_loading(field_names)[source]ÔÉÅ

Add the given list of model field names to the set of fields to retrieve when the SQL is executed (‚Äúimmediate loading‚Äù fields). The field names replace any existing immediate loading field names. If there are field names already specified for deferred loading, remove those names from the new field_names before storing the new names for immediate loading. (That is, immediate loading overrides any existing immediate values, but respects existing deferrals.)

set_annotation_mask(names)[source]ÔÉÅ

Set the mask of annotations that will be returned by the SELECT.

append_annotation_mask(names)[source]ÔÉÅ
set_extra_mask(names)[source]ÔÉÅ

Set the mask of extra select items that will be returned by SELECT. Don‚Äôt remove them from the Query since they might be used later.

set_values(fields)[source]ÔÉÅ
property annotation_select[source]ÔÉÅ

Return the dictionary of aggregate columns that are not masked and should be used in the SELECT clause. Cache this result for performance.

property extra_select[source]ÔÉÅ
trim_start(names_with_path)[source]ÔÉÅ

Trim joins from the start of the join path. The candidates for trim are the PathInfos in names_with_path structure that are m2m joins.

Also set the select column so the start matches the join.

This method is meant to be used for generating the subquery joins & cols in split_exclude().

Return a lookup usable for doing outerq.filter(lookup=self) and a boolean indicating if the joins in the prefix contain a LEFT OUTER join. _

is_nullable(field)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check if the given field should be treated as nullable.

Some backends treat ‚Äò‚Äô as null and Django treats such fields as nullable for those backends. In such situations field.null can be False even if we should treat the field as nullable.
